Basically it's a three executive structure at every store- store manager and two assistant store managers. That's the top and that's where the money is. You are salaried and well paid. The other managers are area supervisors. Those are hourly managers. Pay is OK. But not if you want to support a family or even get ahead in this world. You need to be an exec for that. Great! That's who I saw coming in as training and then being shipped off in 30 days to run a store. No Kohl's experience! They would respond to these "fiishing" postings - manager for xxx market. It's not a real opening, but people from outside of the company respond, get flash training which is nowhere near what you need to even be an area supervisor and given a store. No posting.
There were no internal job postings for a top spot that I saw. Not that it woud matter - I still think they would forgo anyone from within and go from the outside.

Management is very flaky with schedules, sometimes they post updates and then unpost them so you have no idea when your actual shift is, there's always a possibility of them moving you around. This is my biggest con: management doesn't communicate with you very often about your position. I started working before the seasonal period, my work account said I was a regular part time worker. However, management saw me as seasonal and didn't even tell me I was fired, I knew from a termination email. If they had elaborated that even if I had applied before holiday season that I would be considered seasonal, I wouldn't have applied, as I am looking to work for a least a year for the experience. Training is almost non existent for new employees. If hired here, expect to be lost for the first few months. You can have a perfectly recovered department and you won't receive any recognition. For employees that work on the registers, if you don't get credit, you won't get hours. 

Meeting arbitrary credit metrics is all upper management cares about. If your store isn't meeting goals, the stores funding goes down. This leads to less payroll for the store and reduced hours for everyone. Because the store can't schedule the amount of employees they need to keep the store up due to the reduced payroll, the store falls deeper into the metrics hole. Instead of supporting stores who are slipping, kohls will just push them down and let them fail.

As a final con, their handling of the pandemic has been half-hearted at best and criminally negligent at worst. Any precautions you see are just for show and almost all sanitary practices are not enforced. Getting to meet different people and work a variety of jobs in the store - if you're a good employee they let you move depts & they promote from within
Fairly good benefits if you're full time
cons:
One or two bad managers can spoil the work environment for the whole store!!
Pay is not great if you're part time
Best thing to do is just do your thing but don't care too much about your work, or it will wear you down over time
Advice to Management
After working at Kohl's at various locations and in various full and part time positions for 7 years, I can say it really depends on the store. High volume stores are less fun to work at because the constant onslaught of customers and freight really wears down everyone's morale. And depending who is in management, workplace politics can really become toxic. But if things are good, or you're able to stay detached from all that, it can be an enjoyable, laid back place to work. If you're at a high volume store they often don't fully train you. Expect to be given a 'buddy' your first day or two and that's pretty much it - and that person may or may not train you well on processes and procedures. Jobs like service desk have a lot of technical knowledge that it actually tales months to learn because there is not much formal training - High turnover makes them not really invest in someone until they've been working there 6-12 months or longer. The company generally has very loyal shoppers and a well cultivated inner culture (with the exception of some burned out and very sour mgrs) so if they can survive the pandemic and capture the millennial market I expect they'll do well.
